content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 3 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would reason that the best strategy to maximize my earnings in this game is to consider the payoff for each possible pair of moves: R-R (45$), R-B (0$), B-R (42$), and B-B (12$).

If we assume that the anonymous player is rational, they will also try to maximize their earnings. Given the same payoffs, it's reasonable to expect them to make similar choices as I do.

However, since the game has 3 rounds, there are more potential outcomes than just a single pair of moves. For instance, if we both pick R in the first round and get 45$, we'll both have incentives to stick with R in the following rounds due to the higher payoff, but the anonymous player might expect this and switch to B for a better outcome.

On the other hand, picking B in the first round will result in a lower payout of 12$, but it opens up the possibility of switching to R later on if we observe that the opponent also follows this pattern (picking B in the first round and then R in the subsequent rounds). This could potentially lead to earning 45$ in each of the last two rounds.

Considering these factors, a possible strategy would be to mix both choices evenly across all three rounds, as it may confuse the opponent about our predicted behavior, making it harder for them to maximize their own earnings. In this case, my choice could be {R}, but I might also choose {B} in one or more of the following rounds to keep the opponent guessing.

Ultimately, since both strategies (picking R every round and mixing choices) seem reasonable based on the game's structure, I would lean towards mixing choices to add an element of unpredictability and increase my chances of earning 45$ in at least one round.
